item.title: Efficient Controlled Phase Gradients
item.description:
The phase gradient is a useful, but under-appreciated, quantum operation. When you apply a phase gradient to a register, each computational basis state $|k\rangle$ is phased by an amount proportional to $k$:

$$\text{Grad}^t = \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} |k\rangle \langle k| \exp(i \tau t k / N)$$

item.title: Thinking of Operations as Controls
item.description:
Controlled operations are a core part of quantum computation. Not strictly necessary, since any two-qubit gate tends to be sufficient for universal quantum computation, but certainly common.
